makers.displaydate: born 1978, Lubumbashi, Democratic Republic of the Congo; active Brussels, Belgium, and Lubumbashi
makers.displaymaker: Sammy Baloji, born 1978, Lubumbashi, Democratic Republic of the Congo; active Brussels, Belgium, and Lubumbashi

texts.textentryhtml: The artist's studio; [Galerie Imane Farès, Paris, France]; purchased by Princeton University Art Museum, October 2023.

In this image, one in a series of photomontages called Mémoire, Baloji juxtaposes two color photographs of abandoned copper mines in present-day Lubumbashi, his hometown, with a black-and-white photograph of a group of African miners and their European supervisor from the archives of the now-defunct Union Minière du Haut-Katanga. With Baloji’s intervention, the miners seem to proudly pose, in their work gear, in front of a wasteland of rusting steel. The post-apocalyptic composition reveals the environmental and socioeconomic damage caused by the mining industry.

Baloji’s work shows how the colonial exploitation of mineral resources in Congo has continued to affect the postcolonial condition of the country, marked by despair, loss, emptiness, and decay. His work invites us to reflect on the complex and contradictory relationship between Lubumbashi and its mining heritage.

Iheanyichukwu Onwuegbucha, PhD candidate, Department of Art & Archaeology, Princeton University
